Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Forced Migrants Encountering the Refugee Regime

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will analyze the relationship between migration management practices of recipient states in the West and the lived experiences of Syrian forced migrants seeking to escape the ongoing civil war in Syria via Jordan. Taken together, state migration policies, refugee laws, and international agreements constitute what is here termed the "refugee regime" - a set of institutional practices through which the migration policies of countries in the West and the Middle East have become increasingly interconnected. This research draws attention to (1) the transnational activities of state agencies, humanitarian organizations, and non-state actors in managing forced migration, and (2) forced migrants' experiences along their journeys. In doing so, this research re-situates the politics of migration management from a top-down disembodied conception to one informed by the everyday encounters, narratives, and struggles of forced migrants themselves. This research will make important contributions to the field of political geography and broader interdisciplinary debates in refugee studies, security and border studies, and feminist methodology. This study further seeks to interrogate popular representations of forced migrants as passive victims or burdens on the welfare state. Findings from this research will inform public debates about Syrian forced migrants through a series of public information workshops and policy briefs. Research findings will be disseminated to wider society in order to foster a better understanding of forced migrants' lives and the challenges that migrants' face.
Findings from this research will also inform the co-PI's undergraduate teaching on international migration, transnationalism, and geography. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Award, this project will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an independent research career.

This project responds to calls for studies on how migration management works across national borders and how migrants experience and negotiate their journeys between places of departure and arrival. It does so by answering two central research questions: 1) How is the refugee regime constituted across transnational space? 2) How do Syrian forced migrants experience the refugee regime across their migration trajectory and once they arrive in their final destination? In order to answer these questions this project comprises archival research, interviews, and participatory mapping with Syrian forced migrants, as well as interviews with staff of state and non-state institutions. Using these methods, this research contributes new findings to scholarship on the securitization of migration and the changing geographies of borders and migration management.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant from the National Science Foundation allowed a female early-career researcher to conduct a timely and innovative in-depth study on Western states’ management of Syrian forced migrants. Specifically, the goal of this research was to examine how Denmark’s migration management practices extend across borders and are encountered by Syrian forced migrants alongside their migration trajectories. Situated in Jordan and Denmark, this study provides important insights into the nature and repercussions of the Danish state’s response to Syrian forced migrants, both domestically and abroad.

The NSF DDRI grant provided the co-PI with the resources to conduct qualitative research during the summer and fall of 2016. The co-PI carried out archival research at the Danish State Archive, collected legal and policy documents from a range of institutions, and interviewed 26 representatives of humanitarian organizations and Danish state officials working in Jordan and Denmark. The co-PI also conducted 40 interviews and 4 participatory mapping workshops with Syrian forced migrants living in Denmark. When needed, these interviews and workshops were conducted with the help of a Syrian immigrant trained by the co-PI who served as an interpreter and moderator.

Based on this in-depth research, the co-PI uncovered how Denmark and the Middle East have become increasingly interconnected through management practices targeting Syrian forced migrants. With declining public support for providing asylum and refugee re-settlement in Denmark, the Danish state has introduced a set of new strategies that seek to contain and manage Syrian forced migrants in countries in close proximity to Syria. By tracing these strategies, this research reveals how migration management takes place through complex networks of collaboration involving an array of state and non-state actors and entities such as humanitarian workers, state officials, material goods, aid, ideas and technical expertise moving between Denmark and Jordan.

This research further demonstrates how national immigration policies and regulations affect people within and beyond Denmark. Since 2015, the Danish parliament has passed more than thirty-five amendments to the Danish Immigration Law devised to make Denmark a less ‘attractive’ destination for forced migrants with the goal of deterring them from seeking asylum in Denmark. So while ostensibly domestic in character, these initiatives have nevertheless attempted to regulate populations living outside of Danish territory. Yet, this research reveals that many Syrian forced migrants arrived in Denmark by contingent circumstance rather than by design. The majority of the Syrians whom the co-PI spoke with initially fled to countries neighboring Syria. Only later, when it became clear to them that they could no longer return to Syria did they begin to plan their journeys towards Europe, often with limited knowledge of where they might end up. Furthermore, the co-PI found that the majority of the informants were middle or upper middle class and did not directly encounter humanitarian organizations or receive aid alongside their journeys. These findings highlight the importance of how socio-economic differentials shape migrants’ ability to move geographically, and influence how migrants experience the journey.

This research reveals how recent changes to Danish Immigration Law and related regulations influence multiple aspects of Syrian forced migrants’ lives in Denmark. The co-PI found that Syrians experience dire poverty, feelings of sadness, and lose close ties and intimate relations with family members left behind in Syria. They also frequently worry about the possibility of losing their refugee protection status. Many of Syrians with whom the co-PI spoke with described Danish immigration policies as a war against them, indicating the traumatizing and stigmatizing repercussions of these initiatives on many forced migrants currently residing in Europe.

The intellectual merit of this research lies in its approach to the geopolitics of migration management. By bringing together feminist work on transnationalism and subaltern geopolitics, this research illustrates how migration management practices reach beyond national borders and connect places in unexpected ways. In doing so, this study contributes to scholarship on the changing geographies of migration management by forging linkages between geography and broader interdisciplinary debates across refugee studies, border studies, and feminist methodology.

Finally, the findings from this project are applicable to the United States and other countries receiving refugees. This project has generated important knowledge that informs undergraduate teaching in courses on Europe, the Middle East, and migration. Through public presentations and op-eds for newspapers in Denmark and Kentucky, this study also provides the broader public with a better understanding of the multiple challenges forced migrants negotiate along their journeys and in exile.
